texts.definition: Uncertainty in a game which stems from not being aware of an existent solution to a challenge.
markups: <style="Definition">Uncertainty in a game which stems from not being aware of an existent solution to a challenge.</style>

Players of games are often tasks with trying to reach a goal without knowing exactly how to reach that goal. A game has <style="CurrentLink">Solution Uncertainty</style> when this challenge takes the form of mainly having to do with figuring out what actions to do, rather than doing them, although a solution might not actually exist.

Note: ''Uncertainty that comes from the possibility of players failing to perform an action or series of actions is covered by the pattern <style="Link"><link="performance-uncertainty">Performance Uncertainty</link></style>.''

<style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Category:Puzzles">Puzzles</link></style> such as <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Jigsaw%20Puzzles">Jigsaw Puzzles</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Solitaire">Solitaire</link></style>, and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Tangram">Tangram</link></style> all built upon <style="CurrentLink">Solution Uncertainty</style> to provide gameplay for players without requiring other players to participate. <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Alchemists">Alchemists</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Battleship">Battleship</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Cluedo">Cluedo</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Mastermind">Mastermind</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Mystery%20of%20the%20Abbey">Mystery of the Abbey</link></style>, and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Ricochet%20Robots">Ricochet Robots</link></style> are examples of multiplayer games that build upon similar <style="CurrentLink">Solution Uncertainty</style>.

Examples of computer-based <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Category:Puzzle%20Games">Puzzle Games</link></style> relying on <style="CurrentLink">Solution Uncertainty</style> include <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Angry%20Birds">Angry Birds</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Continuity">Continuity</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Cursor*10">Cursor*10</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Drop%207">Drop 7</link></style>, and the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Portal%20series">Portal series</link></style>. <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Category:Adventure%20Games">Adventure Games</link></style> such as <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/King's%20Quest%20series">King's Quest series</link></style>, the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Leisure%20Suit%20Larry%20series">Leisure Suit Larry series</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Maniac%20Mansion">Maniac Mansion</link></style>, and the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Myst%20series">Myst series</link></style> are similar but combine puzzle solving with exploration of an environment and the telling of a story.

<style="CurrentLink">Solution Uncertainty</style> is created by introducing <style="Link"><link="complex-gameplay">Complex Gameplay</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Imperfect%20Information">Imperfect Information</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="uncertainty-information">Uncertainty of Information</link></style>, or a combination of these. It is however important to note that a solution must not necessarily exist, the important thing is that players experience that a solution might exist. Similarly, <style="CurrentLink">Solution Uncertainty</style> can be constructed to allow for <style="Link"><link="trial-error-solutions">Trial and Error Solutions</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="lucky-guess-solutions">Lucky Guess Solutions</link></style>.

<style="Link"><link="strategic-knowledge">Strategic Knowledge</link></style> can ruin games based on <style="CurrentLink">Solution Uncertainty</style> if the solution can become apparent due to the knowledge players can bring over from other game instances. It can however also be a way of modifying <style="CurrentLink">Solution Uncertainty</style>  so that players may have an advantage in finding solutions if they have <style="Link"><link="strategic-knowledge">Strategic Knowledge</link></style>.

The use of <style="Link"><link="ai-players">AI Players</link></style> requires extra consideration when it comes to using <style="CurrentLink">Solution Uncertainty</style> in a game since human players and <style="Link"><link="ai-players">AI Players</link></style> most likely have very different cognitive abilities and what can be difficult for one category of players to find can be trivial for the other.

The most basic consequence of <style="CurrentLink">Solution Uncertainty</style> is that it creates <style="Link"><link="uncertainty-outcome">Uncertainty of Outcome</link></style> in games. This often leads to <style="Link"><link="puzzle-solving">Puzzle Solving</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="tactical-planning">Tactical Planning</link></style>, which in turn can make for <style="Link"><link="challenging-gameplay">Challenging Gameplay</link></style> or lead to players suffering from <style="Link"><link="analysis-paralysis">Analysis Paralysis</link></style>. A slightly more unintuitive effect of <style="CurrentLink">Solution Uncertainty</style> is that is can lead to a player becoming the target of a <style="Link"><link="surprise-attacks">Surprise Attacks</link></style> due to an inability of foreseeing a potential attack. <style="CurrentLink">Solution Uncertainty</style> can help make it impossible to know exactly who will win, and can thereby support <style="Link"><link="winner-gameplay-ends">Winner determined after Gameplay Ends</link></style>.

While <style="CurrentLink">Solution Uncertainty</style> does not automatically create <style="Link"><link="no-direct-player-influence">No Direct Player Influence</link></style>, it does provide a basis for making this type of gameplay in that it opens up for players considering how to manipulate a game state rather than simply manipulating it.

Games that rely heavily on <style="CurrentLink">Solution Uncertainty</style> typically works badly with <style="Link"><link="further-player-improvement-potential">Further Player Improvement Potential</link></style>. This since the former relies on being uncertain that there is a solution or how to reach it and having found one in no way guarantees that there exists a better solution or that players have any gameplay reason to try and find a better one even if one is possible.
